american_poetry.title: I Hear America Singing
american_poetry.author: Walt Whitman
american_poetry.fullText:
I hear America singing, the varied carols I hear,
Those of mechanics, each one singing his as it should be blithe and strong,
The carpenter singing his as he measures his plank or beam,
The mason singing his as he makes ready for work, or leaves off work,
The boatman singing what belongs to him in his boat, the deckhand singing on the steamboat deck,
The shoemaker singing as he sits on his bench, the hatter singing as he stands,
The wood-cutter's song, the ploughboy's on his way in the morning, or at noon intermission or at sundown,
The delicious singing of the mother, or of the young wife at work, or of the girl sewing or washing,
Each singing what belongs to him or her and to none else,
The day what belongs to the day—at night the party of young fellows, robust, friendly,
Singing with open mouths their strong melodious songs.
american_poetry.analysis: Whitman celebrates the diversity and dignity of American workers, each contributing their unique voice to the national chorus. The poem embodies democratic ideals and the value of individual contribution.
american_poetry.historicalContext: Written during America's industrial expansion, reflecting optimism about the nation's potential and the dignity of labor.

american_poetry.title: Because I could not stop for Death
american_poetry.author: Emily Dickinson
american_poetry.fullText:
Because I could not stop for Death –
He kindly stopped for me –
The Carriage held but just Ourselves –
And Immortality.

We slowly drove – He knew no haste
And I had put away
My labor and my leisure too,
For His Civility –

We passed the School, where Children strove
At Recess – in the Ring –
We passed the Fields of Gazing Grain –
We passed the Setting Sun –

Or rather – He passed us –
The Dews drew quivering and chill –
For only Gossamer, my Gown –
My Tippet – only Tulle –

We paused before a House that seemed
A Swelling of the Ground –
The Roof was scarcely visible –
The Cornice – in the Ground –

Since then – 'tis Centuries – and yet
Feels shorter than the Day
I first surmised the Horses' Heads
Were toward Eternity –
american_poetry.analysis: Dickinson personifies Death as a courteous gentleman caller, transforming the fear of death into a peaceful journey. The poem's gentle tone contrasts with its profound subject matter.
american_poetry.historicalContext: Written during the Civil War era, reflecting 19th-century attitudes toward death and the afterlife.

american_poetry.title: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock
american_poetry.author: T.S. Eliot
american_poetry.fullText:
Let us go then, you and I,
When the evening is spread out against the sky
Like a patient etherized upon a table;
Let us go, through certain half-deserted streets,
The muttering retreats
Of restless nights in one-night cheap hotels
And sawdust restaurants with oyster-shells:
Streets that follow like a tedious argument
Of insidious intent
To lead you to an overwhelming question ...
Oh, do not ask, "What is it?"
Let us go and make our visit.

In the room the women come and go
Talking of Michelangelo.

The yellow fog that rubs its back upon the window-panes,
The yellow smoke that rubs its muzzle on the window-panes,
Licked its tongue into the corners of the evening,
Lingered upon the pools that stand in drains,
Let fall upon its back the soot that falls from chimneys,
Slipped by the terrace, made a sudden leap,
And seeing that it was a soft October night,
Curled once about the house, and fell asleep.

And indeed there will be time
For the yellow smoke that slides along the street,
Rubbing its back upon the window-panes;
There will be time, there will be time
To prepare a face to meet the faces that you meet;
There will be time to murder and create,
And time for all the works and days of hands
That lift and drop a question on your plate;
Time for you and time for me,
And time yet for a hundred indecisions,
And for a hundred visions and revisions,
Before the taking of a toast and tea.
american_poetry.analysis: Eliot's modernist masterpiece captures the paralysis and anxiety of modern urban life through Prufrock's internal monologue. The poem revolutionized poetry with its fragmented structure and psychological realism.
american_poetry.historicalContext: Published during WWI, reflecting the disillusionment and fragmentation of modern society.

british_poetry.title: Daffodils
british_poetry.author: William Wordsworth
british_poetry.fullText:
I wandered lonely as a cloud
That floats on high o'er vales and hills,
When all at once I saw a crowd,
A host, of golden daffodils;
Beside the lake, beneath the trees,
Fluttering and dancing in the breeze.

Continuous as the stars that shine
And twinkle on the milky way,
They stretched in never-ending line
Along the margin of a bay:
Ten thousand saw I at a glance,
Tossing their heads in sprightly dance.

The waves beside them danced; but they
Out-did the sparkling waves in glee:
A poet could not but be gay,
In such a jocund company:
I gazed—and gazed—but little thought
What wealth the show to me had brought:

For oft, when on my couch I lie
In vacant or in pensive mood,
They flash upon that inward eye
Which is the bliss of solitude;
And then my heart with pleasure fills,
And dances with the daffodils.
british_poetry.analysis: Wordsworth's celebration of nature's power to heal and inspire exemplifies Romantic poetry. The poem shows how natural beauty can provide lasting comfort and joy through memory.
british_poetry.historicalContext: Written during the height of English Romanticism, inspired by a walk with Dorothy Wordsworth around Ullswater.

british_poetry.title: Ozymandias
british_poetry.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley
british_poetry.fullText:
I met a traveller from an antique land,
Who said—"Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
Stand in the desert. . . . Near them, on the sand,
Half sunk a shattered visage lies, whose frown,
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them, and the heart that fed;
And on the pedestal, these words appear:
My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings;
Look on my Works, ye Mighty, and despair!
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal Wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away."
british_poetry.analysis: Shelley's sonnet explores the transience of earthly power and the inevitable decay of all human achievements. The irony of the boastful inscription amid ruins emphasizes the poem's theme.
british_poetry.historicalContext: Written in response to the acquisition of a statue of Ramesses II by the British Museum, reflecting on the fall of empires.

british_poetry.title: Do not go gentle into that good night
british_poetry.author: Dylan Thomas
british_poetry.fullText:
Do not go gentle into that good night,
Old age should burn and rave at close of day;
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Though wise men at their end know dark is right,
Because their words had forked no lightning they
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Good men, the last wave by, crying how bright
Their frail deeds might have danced in a green bay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Wild men who caught and sang the sun in flight,
And learn, too late, they grieved it on its way,
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Grave men, near death, who see with blinding sight
Blind eyes could blaze like meteors and be gay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

And you, my father, there on the sad height,
Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray.
Do not go gentle into that good night.
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.
british_poetry.analysis: Thomas's villanelle passionately argues against passive acceptance of death. Written for his dying father, it celebrates the human spirit's refusal to surrender without a fight.
british_poetry.historicalContext: Written as Thomas's father was dying, reflecting the poet's own struggle with mortality and loss.

japanese_poetry.title: Spring Rain
japanese_poetry.author: Matsuo Bashō
japanese_poetry.fullText:
Spring rain—
under trees on the mountain path
drops keep falling.
japanese_poetry.originalText:
山路来て
何やらゆかし
すみれ草
japanese_poetry.analysis: This haiku captures the gentle persistence of spring rain, suggesting both renewal and the continuous cycle of nature. The image evokes tranquility and natural harmony.
japanese_poetry.historicalContext: Written during Bashō's famous journey to the northern provinces, documented in 'The Narrow Road to the Deep North.'

japanese_poetry.title: Butterfly
japanese_poetry.author: Matsuo Bashō
japanese_poetry.fullText:
A butterfly—
tempting the cat
with its dance.
japanese_poetry.originalText:
蝶々や
猫をまねく
舞踊かな
japanese_poetry.analysis: This playful haiku captures a moment of natural interaction, showing how beauty can be both alluring and dangerous. The butterfly's dance becomes a metaphor for life's temptations.
japanese_poetry.historicalContext: Reflects Bashō's keen observation of everyday moments and his ability to find profound meaning in simple interactions.

japanese_poetry.title: Tanka: Cherry Blossoms
japanese_poetry.author: Ki no Tsurayuki
japanese_poetry.fullText:
In this world
nothing lasts forever—
even the cherry blossoms
fall and scatter
in the mountain wind.
japanese_poetry.originalText:
世の中は
何か常なる
飛鳥川
昨日の淵ぞ
今日は瀬になる
japanese_poetry.analysis: This tanka reflects the Buddhist concept of impermanence (mono no aware), using cherry blossoms as a metaphor for the transient nature of all existence.
japanese_poetry.historicalContext: From the Kokin Wakashū, one of Japan's earliest imperial poetry anthologies, representing classical court poetry.

french_poetry.title: L'Albatros
french_poetry.author: Charles Baudelaire
french_poetry.fullText:
Often, to amuse themselves, the men of a crew
Catch albatrosses, those vast sea-birds
That indolently follow, flying companions,
The ship gliding on the bitter gulfs.

Scarcely have they placed them on the planks,
Than these kings of the azure, clumsy and ashamed,
Piteously let their great white wings
Drag like oars beside them.

This winged traveler, how awkward and weak he is!
He, so beautiful before, how comic and ugly!
One pokes his beak with a pipe,
Another mimics, limping, the infirm who flew!

The Poet is like this prince of the clouds
Who haunts the tempest and laughs at the archer;
Exiled on the ground in the midst of hootings,
His giant wings prevent him from walking.
french_poetry.originalText:
Souvent, pour s'amuser, les hommes d'équipage
Prennent des albatros, vastes oiseaux des mers,
Qui suivent, indolents compagnons de voyage,
Le navire glissant sur les gouffres amers.

À peine les ont-ils déposés sur les planches,
Que ces rois de l'azur, maladroits et honteux,
Laissent piteusement leurs grandes ailes blanches
Comme des avirons traîner à côté d'eux.

Ce voyageur ailé, comme il est gauche et veule!
Lui, naguère si beau, qu'il est comique et laid!
L'un agace son bec avec un brûle-gueule,
L'autre mime, en boitant, l'infirme qui volait!

Le Poète est semblable au prince des nuées
Qui hante la tempête et se rit de l'archer;
Exilé sur le sol au milieu des huées,
Ses ailes de géant l'empêchent de marcher.
french_poetry.analysis: Baudelaire uses the albatross as a metaphor for the poet's condition—magnificent in their natural element but awkward and misunderstood in ordinary society.
french_poetry.historicalContext: From 'Les Fleurs du mal,' this poem reflects the Romantic notion of the artist as an outsider, misunderstood by society.

french_poetry.title: Le Pont Mirabeau
french_poetry.author: Guillaume Apollinaire
french_poetry.fullText:
Under the Mirabeau Bridge flows the Seine
And our loves
Must I remember them
Joy always followed pain

Let night come let the hour sound
The days go by I remain

Hand in hand let us stay face to face
While under
The bridge of our arms passes
The wave of eternal glances

Let night come let the hour sound
The days go by I remain

Love goes by like this flowing water
Love goes by
How slow life is
And how violent hope is

Let night come let the hour sound
The days go by I remain

The days pass and the weeks pass
Neither time past
Nor loves return
Under the Mirabeau Bridge flows the Seine

Let night come let the hour sound
The days go by I remain
french_poetry.originalText:
Sous le pont Mirabeau coule la Seine
Et nos amours
Faut-il qu'il m'en souvienne
La joie venait toujours après la peine

Vienne la nuit sonne l'heure
Les jours s'en vont je demeure

Les mains dans les mains restons face à face
Tandis que sous
Le pont de nos bras passe
Des éternels regards l'onde si lasse

Vienne la nuit sonne l'heure
Les jours s'en vont je demeure

L'amour s'en va comme cette eau courante
L'amour s'en va
Comme la vie est lente
Et comme l'Espoir est violent

Vienne la nuit sonne l'heure
Les jours s'en vont je demeure

Passent les jours et passent les semaines
Ni temps passé
Ni les amours reviennent
Sous le pont Mirabeau coule la Seine

Vienne la nuit sonne l'heure
Les jours s'en vont je demeure
french_poetry.analysis: Apollinaire's melancholic meditation on lost love uses the flowing Seine as a metaphor for time's passage. The refrain emphasizes the speaker's endurance despite change.
french_poetry.historicalContext: Written during Apollinaire's relationship with Marie Laurencin, reflecting the pain of romantic loss and the persistence of memory.

spanish_poetry.title: Romance Sonámbulo
spanish_poetry.author: Federico García Lorca
spanish_poetry.fullText:
Green, how I want you green.
Green wind. Green branches.
The ship out on the sea
and the horse on the mountain.
With the shade around her waist
she dreams on her balcony,
green flesh, her hair green,
with eyes of cold silver.
Green, how I want you green.
Under the gypsy moon,
all things are watching her
and she cannot see them.
spanish_poetry.originalText:
Verde que te quiero verde.
Verde viento. Verdes ramas.
El barco sobre la mar
y el caballo en la montaña.
Con la sombra en la cintura
ella sueña en su baranda,
verde carne, pelo verde,
con ojos de fría plata.
Verde que te quiero verde.
Bajo la luna gitana,
las cosas le están mirando
y ella no puede mirarlas.
spanish_poetry.analysis: Lorca's haunting ballad uses the color green as a symbol of desire, nature, and the mysterious. The repetitive 'Verde que te quiero verde' creates a hypnotic, dreamlike quality.
spanish_poetry.historicalContext: Part of 'Romancero Gitano,' reflecting Lorca's fascination with Andalusian gypsy culture and Spanish folk traditions.

spanish_poetry.title: Soneto XXIII
spanish_poetry.author: Garcilaso de la Vega
spanish_poetry.fullText:
While there is still the color of the rose
and of the lily in your lovely face,
and your bright, honest glance can set ablaze
the heart and yet restrain it as it goes;

and while the wind still plays among and blows
the golden hair apart in its bright maze,
when it flies free and in the sun's bright rays
it shines—the hillside's envy as it glows;

pluck from your happy spring the sweet delight
before time's bitter step turns all to ground
with snow the hilltop of your head around.

The rose will wither in the wind's despite,
age change the course and current that you are:
if you would not be sorry, love today.
spanish_poetry.originalText:
En tanto que de rosa y azucena
se muestra la color en vuestro gesto,
y que vuestro mirar ardiente, honesto,
enciende al corazón y lo refrena;

y en tanto que el cabello, que en la vena
del oro se escogió, con vuelo presto,
por el hermoso cuello blanco, enhiesto,
el viento mueve, esparce y desordena:

coged de vuestra alegre primavera
el dulce fruto, antes que el tiempo airado
cubra de nieve la hermosa cumbre;

marchitará la rosa el viento helado.
Todo lo mudará la edad ligera
por no hacer mudanza en su costumbre.
spanish_poetry.analysis: Garcilaso's sonnet follows the classical 'carpe diem' theme, urging the beloved to enjoy youth and beauty before time destroys them. The poem exemplifies Spanish Golden Age poetry.
spanish_poetry.historicalContext: Written during the Spanish Renaissance, influenced by Italian Petrarchan sonnets and classical themes.

german_poetry.title: Der Erlkönig
german_poetry.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
german_poetry.fullText:
Who rides so late through night and wind?
It is the father with his child;
He holds the boy close in his arms,
He clasps him securely, he holds him warm.

'My son, why do you hide your face so anxiously?'
'Father, don't you see the Erlking?
The Erlking with crown and train?'
'My son, it's a streak of mist.'

'You dear child, come, go with me!
Very lovely games I'll play with you;
Many colored flowers are on the shore,
My mother has many golden garments.'

'My father, my father, and don't you hear
What the Erlking quietly promises me?'
'Be calm, stay calm, my child;
The wind is rustling in the dry leaves.'

'Do you want to come with me, pretty boy?
My daughters shall wait on you finely;
My daughters lead the nightly dance,
And rock and dance and sing you to sleep.'

'My father, my father, and don't you see there
The Erlking's daughters in the gloomy place?'
'My son, my son, I see it clearly:
The old willows look so gray.'

'I love you, your beautiful form entices me;
And if you're not willing, then I'll use force.'
'My father, my father, he's grabbing me now!
The Erlking has hurt me!'

The father shudders, he rides swiftly on,
He holds the groaning child in his arms,
Reaches the farm with effort and need;
In his arms, the child was dead.
german_poetry.originalText:
Wer reitet so spät durch Nacht und Wind?
Es ist der Vater mit seinem Kind;
Er hat den Knaben wohl in dem Arm,
Er faßt ihn sicher, er hält ihn warm.

'Mein Sohn, was birgst du so bang dein Gesicht?'
'Siehst, Vater, du den Erlkönig nicht?
Den Erlenkönig mit Kron' und Schweif?'
'Mein Sohn, es ist ein Nebelstreif.'

'Du liebes Kind, komm, geh mit mir!
Gar schöne Spiele spiel' ich mit dir;
Manch' bunte Blumen sind an dem Strand,
Meine Mutter hat manch gülden Gewand.'

'Mein Vater, mein Vater, und hörest du nicht,
Was Erlenkönig mir leise verspricht?'
'Sei ruhig, bleibe ruhig, mein Kind;
In dürren Blättern säuselt der Wind.'

'Willst, feiner Knabe, du mit mir gehn?
Meine Töchter sollen dich warten schön;
Meine Töchter führen den nächtlichen Reihn
Und wiegen und tanzen und singen dich ein.'

'Mein Vater, mein Vater, und siehst du nicht dort
Erlkönigs Töchter am düstern Ort?'
'Mein Sohn, mein Sohn, ich seh' es genau:
Es scheinen die alten Weiden so grau.'

'Ich liebe dich, mich reizt deine schöne Gestalt;
Und bist du nicht willig, so brauch' ich Gewalt.'
'Mein Vater, mein Vater, jetzt faßt er mich an!
Erlkönig hat mir ein Leids getan!'

Dem Vater grauset's; er reitet geschwind,
Er hält in Armen das ächzende Kind,
Erreicht den Hof mit Mühe und Not;
In seinen Armen das Kind war tot.
german_poetry.analysis: Goethe's dramatic ballad tells of a father's desperate ride to save his child from the supernatural Erlking. The poem explores themes of innocence, supernatural terror, and tragic loss.
german_poetry.historicalContext: Based on Danish folklore, this poem became one of the most famous German ballads and inspired Schubert's famous art song.

german_poetry.title: Wandrers Nachtlied
german_poetry.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
german_poetry.fullText:
Over all the hilltops
Is quiet now,
In all the treetops
Hearest thou
Hardly a breath;
The birds are asleep in the trees:
Wait, soon like these
Thou too shalt rest.
german_poetry.originalText:
Über allen Gipfeln
Ist Ruh,
In allen Wipfeln
Spürest du
Kaum einen Hauch;
Die Vögelein schweigen im Walde.
Warte nur, balde
Ruhest du auch.
german_poetry.analysis: This brief, profound poem captures a moment of perfect natural tranquility while suggesting the universal peace that comes with death. Its simplicity belies its philosophical depth.
german_poetry.historicalContext: Written during Goethe's travels, this poem reflects Romantic ideals about nature's spiritual significance and the search for inner peace.

russian_poetry.title: I Remember a Wonderful Moment
russian_poetry.author: Alexander Pushkin
russian_poetry.fullText:
I remember a wonderful moment:
You appeared before me,
Like a fleeting vision,
Like a genius of pure beauty.

In the torments of hopeless sadness,
In the turmoil of noisy vanity,
Your gentle voice sounded long to me,
And I dreamed of your dear features.

Years passed. Rebellious storms
Scattered the former dreams,
And I forgot your tender voice,
Your heavenly features.

In the wilderness, in the gloom of confinement,
My days dragged on quietly,
Without divinity, without inspiration,
Without tears, without life, without love.

My soul awakened:
And here you appeared again,
Like a fleeting vision,
Like a genius of pure beauty.

And my heart beats in ecstasy,
And for it have risen again
Divinity, and inspiration,
And life, and tears, and love.
russian_poetry.originalText:
Я помню чудное мгновенье:
Передо мной явилась ты,
Как мимолетное виденье,
Как гений чистой красоты.

В томленьях грусти безнадежной,
В тревогах шумной суеты,
Звучал мне долго голос нежный
И снились милые черты.

Шли годы. Бурь порыв мятежный
Рассеял прежние мечты,
И я забыл твой голос нежный,
Твои небесные черты.

В глуши, во мраке заточенья
Тянулись тихо дни мои
Без божества, без вдохновенья,
Без слез, без жизни, без любви.

Душе настало пробужденье:
И вот опять явилась ты,
Как мимолетное виденье,
Как гений чистой красоты.

И сердце бьется в упоенье,
И для него воскресли вновь
И божество, и вдохновенье,
И жизнь, и слезы, и любовь.
russian_poetry.analysis: Pushkin's lyrical masterpiece traces the cycle of love, loss, and renewal. The poem's musical quality and emotional depth make it one of Russian literature's most beloved works.
russian_poetry.historicalContext: Dedicated to Anna Kern, this poem reflects Pushkin's romantic idealism and became the basis for Glinka's famous romance.

russian_poetry.title: The Bronze Horseman
russian_poetry.author: Alexander Pushkin
russian_poetry.fullText:
On the shore of desolate waves
He stood, full of great thoughts,
And gazed into the distance. Before him
The river spread wide; a poor skiff
Raced along it alone. Here and there
On the moss-grown, swampy shore
Black huts showed, the shelter
Of the wretched Finn; and the forest,
Unknown to the rays of the sun
Hidden in fog, murmured around.

And he thought:
'From here we shall threaten the Swede;
Here a city shall be founded
To spite our arrogant neighbor.
Nature has destined us here
To cut a window through to Europe,
To stand with firm foot by the sea.
Hither, over unknown waters,
Ships of every flag will come to visit us,
And we shall feast in the open.'
russian_poetry.originalText:
На берегу пустынных волн
Стоял он, дум великих полн,
И вдаль глядел. Пред ним широко
Река неслася; бедный чёлн
По ней стремился одиноко.
По мшистым, топким берегам
Чернели избы здесь и там,
Приют убогого чухонца;
И лес, неведомый лучам
В тумане спрятанного солнца,
Кругом шумел.

И думал он:
Отсель грозить мы будем шведу,
Здесь будет город заложен
Назло надменному соседу.
Природой здесь нам суждено
В Европу прорубить окно,
Ногою твердой стать при море.
Сюда по новым им волнам
Все флаги в гости будут к нам,
И запируем на просторе.
russian_poetry.analysis: Pushkin's epic poem about Peter the Great's founding of St. Petersburg explores the tension between imperial ambition and human cost, between progress and tradition.
russian_poetry.historicalContext: Written during Nicholas I's reign, the poem reflects on Russian imperial power and the price of modernization.

chinese_poetry.title: Quiet Night Thought
chinese_poetry.author: Li Bai
chinese_poetry.fullText:
Before my bed the moon is shining bright,
I think that it is frost upon the ground.
I raise my head to look at the bright moon,
I lower my head and think of home.
chinese_poetry.originalText:
床前明月光，
疑是地上霜。
举头望明月，
低头思故乡。
chinese_poetry.analysis: Li Bai's simple yet profound poem captures the universal experience of homesickness. The moon serves as a bridge between the speaker's current location and distant home.
chinese_poetry.historicalContext: Written during the Tang Dynasty's golden age, this poem exemplifies classical Chinese poetry's ability to express deep emotion through simple imagery.

chinese_poetry.title: Spring Dawn
chinese_poetry.author: Meng Haoran
chinese_poetry.fullText:
In spring sleep I'm not aware of dawn,
Everywhere I hear the cry of birds.
Last night came the sound of wind and rain—
How many flowers have fallen?
chinese_poetry.originalText:
春眠不觉晓，
处处闻啼鸟。
夜来风雨声，
花落知多少。
chinese_poetry.analysis: This gentle poem captures the drowsy pleasure of spring mornings while subtly acknowledging the transience of beauty through the fallen flowers.
chinese_poetry.historicalContext: From the Tang Dynasty, representing the classical Chinese appreciation for natural cycles and the bittersweet nature of beauty.

indian_poetry.title: Where the mind is without fear
indian_poetry.author: Rabindranath Tagore
indian_poetry.fullText:
Where the mind is without fear and the head is held high
Where knowledge is free
Where the world has not been broken up into fragments
By narrow domestic walls
Where words come out from the depth of truth
Where tireless striving stretches its arms towards perfection
Where the clear stream of reason has not lost its way
Into the dreary desert sand of dead habit
Where the mind is led forward by thee
Into ever-widening thought and action
Into that heaven of freedom, my Father, let my country awake.
indian_poetry.analysis: Tagore's prayer-poem envisions an ideal society free from fear, ignorance, and division. Written during India's struggle for independence, it remains a powerful vision of human potential.
indian_poetry.historicalContext: Written during British colonial rule, this poem became an anthem for Indian independence and continues to inspire movements for freedom worldwide.

indian_poetry.title: The Golden Boat
indian_poetry.author: Rabindranath Tagore
indian_poetry.fullText:
Clouds rumbling in the sky; teeming rain.
I sit on the river bank, sad and alone.
The sheaves lie gathered, harvest has ended,
The river is swollen and fierce in its flow.
As I watch the storm clouds, I see a boat
Golden-sailed, dancing upon the waves.
I call to the boatman, 'Come, take me across!'
He looks at me and smiles, but says nothing.
I beg of him, 'The storm rages, the river is wild,
Take me away from this desolate shore!'
He smiles and says, 'There is room in my boat
For you alone—but not for your harvest.'
'How can I leave my harvest?' I cry,
'It is all I have, the work of my life!'
He says, 'Choose then,' and waits by the shore.
The golden boat rocks in the wind.
I think of my harvest, my life's work,
And I cannot let go, I cannot choose.
The boatman waits, silent and still,
The golden boat dancing upon the waves.
At last the storm passes, the river calms,
And the golden boat sails away.
I remain on the shore with my harvest,
Rich in grain, poor in spirit,
Watching the golden boat disappear
Into the blue of the distant sky.
indian_poetry.originalText:
আমার সোনার তরী
ভরা পূর্ণিমার রাতে
কে যেন ডাকে পারে
ওগো, কোথায় যাবে তুমি
কোথায় যাবে একা
আমার সোনার তরী।
indian_poetry.analysis: Tagore's allegorical poem explores the tension between material attachment and spiritual liberation. The golden boat represents transcendence, while the harvest symbolizes worldly possessions.
indian_poetry.historicalContext: Reflects Tagore's philosophical exploration of detachment and spiritual growth, influenced by both Hindu philosophy and his own mystical experiences.
